content:
This is a nice clash, quite hard but nice anyway.

Only problem is that the validators are much harder than the tests.

The Ruby code I'll share in a reply below passes 100% of the tests, but only 50% of the validators.

The issue is that when checking the Hamming distance my code forgot to be case-insensitive. None of the test cases were robust enough to catch this mistake, but 2 of the validators were ("Bat" and "Not real words").

It would be good to add another test+validator pair, but since you might not be active here, for now I will just swap the "Not real words?" test with the "Not real words" validator, so that my code would now get 75% on both tests and validators and allow for debuggin in-clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Can be done in less than 15 minutes, and it is a nice problem to solve.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A simple yet a good problem for clash of code, good job.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice job, well done
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Seems number of words is correct now, 
Nice problem!
as mentioned also by @ivanarts in the test "I'm Grut!" the number of words is wrong, you may want to correct it

Maybe already mention that the optimal way to correct a word is unique already in the goal section (instead of saving this for the constraints)?
Nice problem though
I think the number of words in the sentence is of no use here for the problem, or am I missing something?

Goal section
* Do you mean "making" instead of "maling"?

* The monospace syntax has not been applied correctly. Please fix it.

Input section
* Suggest to change "Another" to "Each line is a".

* Suggest to change both <<Line N+2:>> and <<Line N+3:>> to <<Next line:>>.

Cases
* Please avoid using Unicode characters. Relevant discussion here: https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/how-to-make-coc-puzzle-with-unicode-characters/188910
Besides, I'm not sure if the uppercase/lowercase functions work correctly on these characters for all programming languages. (Not sure but I think some languages have separate functions for Unicode characters and non-Unicode characters.)

Constraints section
* If you agree to revise per above, the constraint on the characters should be revised accordingly.

Thanks.

Thanks for feedback!

I was thinking about not using unicode, so yes, I changed that.
Thanks for suggestions on input section.
Fixed typo & monospace in goal section.
Moreover useless, it is wrong in some tests as in the 'I am Grut!' tests.
Hm, I'll think about it, thanks for suggestion.

n = gets.to_i
d = n.times.map do
  word = gets.chomp
end
l = gets.to_i
m = message = gets.chomp
x = m.split.reject{|w| d.find{ _1[/^#{w}$/i] } }
r = x.map{|w| d.select{|u| u.size == w.size }.min_by{|u| u.chars.zip(w.chars).count{_1!=_2} } }
x.zip(r).map{|w, u|
  u2 = w.chars.zip(u.chars).map{|c, i| c==c.upcase ? i.upcase : i.downcase }.join
  m.gsub!(w, u2)
}
puts m
It's possibly there for input purposes, useful if someone is taking inputs word by word instead of entire sentence in a language like C/C++. Skippable in these languages too, agreed.
